item.title: Conal Tuohy on "TEI Markup of Headings and Ornaments"
item.dc:creator: Conal Tuohy
item.description:
I would suggest using "rendition". See the definition of @rendition here:
http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-att.global.html
... and the definition of <rendition> here:
http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-rendition.html

In short, you can define a "squashed" or "displaced" rendition and associate it with the appropriate spans of text (e.g. <seg rendition="#displaced">blah blah</seg>).
If you want, you can define the rendition twice: once in natural language and again in a formal language like CSS, and link both these renditions to your <seg> elements.

item.title: Hayim on "TEI Markup of Headings and Ornaments"
item.dc:creator: Hayim
item.description:
I am transcribing and marking up medieval Hebrew manuscripts, and have encountered a phenomenon that the general TEI guidelines do not provide for. Can people recommend good examples of marked up texts or sites that exemplify best practices?

[The problem in brief: Some of the scribes use larger text for headings or labels and these displace text in the line below. Presumably this is marked with @rend on the elements in question, but I am at a loss for an efficient way to do this.]
